<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/siloscape';
	}
</script>

	<!-- This site is optimized with the Yoast SEO Premium plugin v23.1 (Yoast SEO v23.1) - https://yoast.com/wordpress/plugins/seo/ -->
	<title>Siloscape: First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers to Compromise Cloud Environments</title>
	<meta name="description" content="The main purpose of Siloscape is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/siloscape/" />

	<meta property="og:type" content="article" />
	<meta property="og:title" content="Siloscape: First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers to Compromise Cloud Environments" />
	<meta property="og:description" content="The main purpose of Siloscape is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers." />
	<meta property="og:url" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/siloscape/" />

<meta property="og:likes" content="74"/>
<meta property="og:readtime" content="11"/>
<meta property="og:views" content="89,155"/>
<meta property="og:date_created" content="June 7, 2021 at 3:00 AM"/>
<meta property="og:post_length" content="2869"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Cloud Cybersecurity Research"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Malware"/>
<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Daniel Prizmant"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/daniel-prizmant/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>
<meta name="post_tags" content="Cloud,Containers,Kubernetes,Siloscape"/>
<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/image2.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Siloscape: First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers to Compromise Cloud Environments","name":"Siloscape: First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers to Compromise Cloud Environments","description":"The main purpose of Siloscape is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/siloscape\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/siloscape\/","datePublished":"June 7, 2021","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nIn March 2021, I uncovered the first known malware targeting Windows containers, a development that is not surprising given the massive surge in cloud adoption over the past few years. I named the malware Siloscape (sounds like silo escape) because its primary goal is to escape the container, and in Windows this is implemented mainly by a server silo.\r\n\r\nSiloscape is heavily obfuscated malware targeting Kubernetes clusters through Windows containers. Its main purpose is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers.\r\n\r\nCompromising an entire cluster is much more severe than compromising an individual container, as a cluster could run multiple cloud applications whereas an individual container usually runs a single cloud application. For example, the attacker might be able to steal critical information such as usernames and passwords, an organization\u2019s confidential and internal files or even entire databases hosted in the cluster. Such an attack could even be leveraged as a ransomware attack by taking the organization's files hostage. Even worse, with organizations moving to the cloud, many use Kubernetes clusters as their development and testing environments, and a breach of such an environment can lead to devastating software supply chain attacks.\r\n\r\nSiloscape uses the Tor proxy and an .onion domain to anonymously connect to its command and control (C2) server. I managed to gain access to this server. We identified 23 active Siloscape victims and discovered that the server was being used to host 313 users in total, implying that Siloscape was a small part of a broader campaign. I also discovered that this campaign has been taking place for more than a year.\r\n\r\nThis report provides background on Windows container vulnerabilities, gives a technical overview of Siloscape and offers recommendations on best practices for securing Windows containers.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat with Prisma Cloud\u2019s Runtime Protection features.\r\nWindows Server Container Vulnerabilities Overview\r\nOn July 15, 2020, I released an article about Windows container boundaries and how to break them. In that article, I presented a technique for escaping from a container and discussed some potential applications that such an escape can have in the hands of an attacker. The most significant application, and the one I chose to focus on, was an escape from a Windows container node in Kubernetes in order to spread in the cluster.\r\n\r\nMicrosoft originally didn\u2019t consider this issue a vulnerability, based on the reasoning that Windows Server containers are not a security boundary, and therefore each application that is being run inside a container should be treated as if it is executed directly on the host.\r\n\r\nA few weeks after that discussion, I reported the issue to Google because Kubernetes is vulnerable to those issues. Google contacted Microsoft, and after some back and forth, it was determined by Microsoft that an escape from a Windows container to the host, when executed without administrator permissions inside the container, will in fact be considered a vulnerability.\r\n\r\nFollowing this, I discovered Siloscape, which is malware that actively attempts to exploit Windows Server containers in the wild. Siloscape is heavily obfuscated malware targeting Kubernetes through Windows containers (using Server Containers and not Hyper-V). Its main purpose is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers such as, but not limited to, cryptojackers.\r\n\r\nThe malware is characterized by several behaviors and techniques:\r\n\r\n \tTargets common cloud applications such as web servers for initial access, using known vulnerabilities (\u201c1-days\u201d) \u2013 presumably those with a working exploit in the wild.\r\n \tUses Windows container escape techniques to escape the container and gain code execution on the underlying node.\r\n \tAttempts to abuse the node's credentials to spread in the cluster.\r\n \tConnects to its C2 server using the IRC protocol over the Tor network.\r\n \tWaits for further commands.\r\n\r\nThis malware can leverage the computing resources in a Kubernetes cluster for cryptojacking and potentially exfiltrate sensitive data from hundreds of applications running in the compromised clusters.\r\n\r\nInvestigating the C2 server showed that this malware is just a small part of a larger network and that this campaign has been taking place for over a year. Furthermore, I confirmed that this specific part of the campaign was online with active victims at the time of writing.\r\nTechnical Overview\r\nBefore diving into the technical details of Siloscape, it is important to get a better understanding of its overall behavior and flow.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119150\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. Execution flow of Siloscape.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n \tThe attacker achieves remote code execution (RCE) inside a Windows container using a known vulnerability or a vulnerable web page or database.\r\n \tThe attacker executes Siloscape (CloudMalware.exe) with the necessary C2 connection information provided as command line arguments (and not hardcoded inside the binary).\r\n \tSiloscape impersonates CExecSvc.exe to obtain SeTcbPrivilege privileges (this technique is described in detail in my previous article).\r\n \tSiloscape creates a global symbolic link to the host, practically linking its containerized X drive to the host\u2019s C drive.\r\n \tSiloscape searches for the kubectl.exe binary by name and the Kubernetes config file by regular expression on the host, using the global link.\r\n \tSiloscape checks if the compromised node has enough privilege to create new Kubernetes deployments.\r\n \tSiloscape extracts the Tor client to the disk from an archived file using an unzip binary. Both files are packed into the main Siloscape binary.\r\n \tSiloscape connects to the Tor network.\r\n \tUsing the provided command line argument, Siloscape decrypts the C2 server\u2019s password.\r\n \tSiloscape connects to the C2 server using an .onion domain (a domain accessible through the Tor network) provided as a command line argument.\r\n \tSiloscape waits for commands from the C2 and executes them.\r\n\r\nUnlike other malware targeting containers, which are mostly cryptojacking-focused, Siloscape doesn\u2019t actually do anything that will harm the cluster on its own. Instead, it focuses on being undetected and untraceable and opens a backdoor to the cluster.\r\nDefense Evasion and Obfuscation\r\nSiloscape is heavily obfuscated. There are almost no readable strings in the entire binary. While the obfuscation logic itself isn\u2019t complicated, it made reversing this binary frustrating.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119152\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Strings obfuscation as it looks in Interactive Disassembler (IDA).[\/caption]\r\n\r\nEven simple API calls were obfuscated, and instead of just calling the functions, Siloscape made the effort to use the Native API (NTAPI) version of the same function.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119154\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"734\"] Figure 3. Dynamic search of functions in ntdll.dll.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFor example, instead of calling CreateFile, Siloscape calls NtCreateFile. Instead of calling NtCreateFile directly, Siloscape calls it dynamically, meaning it searches for the function name in ntdll.dll at runtime and jumps to its address. Not only that, but it also obfuscates the function and module names and deobfuscates them only at runtime. The end result is malware that is very difficult to detect with static analysis tools and frustrating to reverse engineer.\r\n\r\nSiloscape uses a pair of keys to decrypt the C2 server\u2019s password. One of the most important features of its obfuscation is that one key is hardcoded into the binary, while the other is supplied as a command line argument. I searched for its hash in multiple engines, such as AutoFocus and VirusTotal, and couldn\u2019t find any results. This led me to believe that Siloscape is being compiled uniquely for each new attack, using a unique pair of keys. The hardcoded key makes each binary a little bit different than the rest, which explains why I couldn\u2019t find its hash anywhere. It also makes it impossible to detect Siloscape by hash alone.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119156\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"783\"] Figure 4. Siloscape using Visual Studio Resource Manager.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAnother interesting technique this malware uses is Visual Studio\u2019s Resource Manager. This is a feature built into Visual Studio that allows one to attach basically any file to the original binary and get a pointer to its data with a few simple API calls. Siloscape uses this method to write the Tor archive to the disk, as well as the unzip binary used to open the archive. It also uses Tor to securely connect to its C2.\r\nThe Container Escape\r\nOne of the more interesting things about Siloscape is the way it escapes the container. To execute the system call NtSetInformationSymbolicLink that enables the escape, one must gain SeTcbPrivilege first. There are a few ways to do this. For example, in my tests, I injected a DLL into CExecSvc.exe, which has the relevant privileges, and executed NtSetInformationSymbolicLink from the CExecSvc.exe context. Siloscape, however, uses a technique called Thread Impersonation. This method has little documentation online and even fewer working examples. The most critical function for this technique is the undocumented system call NtImpersonateThread.\r\n\r\nSiloscape mimics CExecSvc.exe privileges by impersonating its main thread and then calls NtSetInformationSymbolicLink on a newly created symbolic link to break out of the container. More specifically, it links its local containerized X drive to the host\u2019s C drive.\r\nChoosing the Cluster\r\nAfter Siloscape creates a link to the host, it will search for two specific files: kubectl.exe and the Kubernetes config file, which normally exists on Kubernetes nodes.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119158\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 5. Siloscape searches for the kubectl.exe binary.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nSiloscape searches for kubectl.exe by name and the config file using a regular expression. The search function takes an extra argument: a pointer to a vector that holds folder names to exclude from the search.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119160\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. Siloscape searches for the config file by regular expression.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhen it calls FindFile to search for the above files, it excludes the folders Program Files, Program Files (x86), Windows and Users. It does this to make the search faster and because it is unlikely the previously mentioned files are in those folders. If both files are found, their paths are saved to a global variable. If the files are not located, Siloscape exits, abandoning the attack.\r\n\r\nAfter Siloscape finds everything it needs to execute kubectl commands, it continues to check if the compromised node actually has enough permissions to use for the attacker\u2019s malicious activities. It does this by executing the kubectl command %ls auth can-i create deployments --kubeconfig=%ls where the strings in the format are replaced by the paths it saved earlier as global variables.\r\nConnecting to the C2 and Supported Commands\r\nAfter getting everything it needs and checking that the compromised node is indeed capable of creating new deployments, Siloscape writes the Tor archive (ZIP) and an unzip binary to the host\u2019s C drive. After extracting Tor, it launches tor.exe to a new thread and waits for it to finish by checking the Tor thread output.\r\n\r\nAfter Tor is up and running, Siloscape uses it to connect to its C2 \u2013 an IRC server, using an onion address that was provided as a command line argument.\r\n\r\nThe server is password-protected. Siloscape uses its first command line argument to decrypt the password by a simple byte by byte XOR. The following is a simplified version of the C2 server\u2019s password decryption:\r\n\r\nchar hardCodedXor[32] = \"HARD_CODED_32_LONG_STRING\"; \r\nchar ircPass[32] = { 0 }; \r\nfor (int i = 0; i &lt; 32; i++) \r\n\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0ircPass[i] = hardCodedXor[i] ^ argv[1][i];\r\n\r\nOnce successfully connected to the IRC server, it issues a JOIN #WindowsKubernetes command to join the WindowsKubernetes IRC channel and then idles there.\r\n\r\nSiloscape allows two types of instructions, one for kubectl supported commands and one for regular Windows cmd commands.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119162\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"523\"] Figure 7. Siloscape comparing the sender\u2019s username to admin.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIt waits for a private message. If one from a user named admin is received, Siloscape follows the following logic:\r\n\r\n \tIf the message starts with a K, it executes a kubectl command to the cluster using the paths it found earlier by running the command %ls %s --kubeconfig=%ls where:\r\n\r\n \tThe first parameter is the global variable of the kubectl\u2019s path.\r\n \tThe second parameter is the message from the admin minus the first character.\r\n \tThe third parameter is the global variable of the config\u2019s path.\r\n\r\n\r\n \tIf the message starts with a C, it simply runs the command minus the first character as a regular Windows cmd command.\r\n\r\nCommand and Control\r\nAfter I reversed the malware, especially the part that handles the C2, I wanted to discover whether this campaign was still up and running.\r\n\r\nI set up a brand new virtual machine, downloaded Tor and started looking for an IRC client that supports SOCKS5, the proxy protocol that is needed in order to connect through Tor. IRC is a very old protocol and is less popular today than it was 20 years ago. Furthermore, IRC came out almost a decade before SOCKS5. I found HexChat, a simple, lightweight IRC client that supports both SOCKS5 and connecting to onion domains.\r\n\r\nWhen our Silospace sample was originally executed, its command line argument for the IRC username was php_35, so I decided to use this username when connecting to the C2 server from HexChat, thinking it would appear legitimate to the attacker.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119164\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. #WindowsKubernetes channel active victims.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nI connected to the server and discovered it was still working. I joined #WindowsKubernetes just like Siloscape does. There were 23 active victims there and a channel operator named admin.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119166\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 9. C2 server shutting down.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nUnfortunately, after about two minutes, I was noticed and kicked out of the server. Two minutes after that, the server was no longer active \u2013 at least not at the original onion domain I used.\r\nWhat Can We Learn?\r\nWhen I went over my findings, the first thing that came to mind is that there were many more active users on the C2 server than I actually saw in the #WindowsKubernetes channel \u2013 313 users in total, to be exact. This implies that the Siloscape malware was just a small part of a bigger campaign.\r\n\r\nSadly, when I connected to the server, the channels list was empty, indicating that the server was configured to not reveal its channels. Therefore, I couldn\u2019t get more information from the channel names.\r\n\r\nThe second and more important detail that stood out was the convention used for the victims\u2019 names. Our name was php_35, and when our sample of Siloscape first executed, it indeed was executed through a vulnerable php instance. The other names clearly suggest the way the attacker managed to achieve code execution (sqlinj probably means SQL injection):\r\n\r\n@admin sqlinj_64 sqlinj_51 php_34 weblogic_12 sqlinj_138 weblogic_19 php_66 sqlinj_87 sqlinj_8 sqlinj_33 sqlinj_114 activemq_5 sqlinj_44 tomcat_9 sqlinj_52 sqlinj_107 redis_10 php_76 sqlinj_28 activemq_25 sqlinj_35 php_8 weblogic_31 php_35\r\n\r\nThe last piece of information I was able to obtain from the C2 is the creation date of the server: Jan. 12, 2020. Note that this doesn\u2019t necessarily mean that Siloscape was created on that date. Instead, it\u2019s likely the campaign started at that time.\r\nConclusion\r\nUnlike most cloud malware, which mostly focuses on resource hijacking and denial of service (DoS), Siloscape doesn\u2019t limit itself to any specific goal. Instead, it opens a backdoor to all kinds of malicious activities.\r\n\r\nAs discussed in my last article, users should follow Microsoft\u2019s guidance recommending not to use Windows containers as a security feature. Microsoft recommends using strictly Hyper-V containers for anything that relies on containerization as a security boundary. Any process running in Windows Server containers should be assumed to have the same privileges as admin on the host, which in this case is the Kubernetes node. If you are running applications in Windows Server containers that need to be secured, we recommend moving these applications to Hyper-V containers.\r\n\r\nFurthermore, administrators should make sure their Kubernetes cluster is securely configured. In particular, a secured Kubernetes cluster won\u2019t be as vulnerable to this specific malware as the nodes\u2019 privileges won\u2019t suffice to create new deployments. In this case, Siloscape will exit.\r\n\r\nSiloscape shows us the importance of container security, as the malware wouldn\u2019t be able to cause any significant damage if not for the container escape. It is critical that organizations keep a well-configured and secured cloud environment to protect against such threats.\r\n\r\nExisting Prisma Cloud capabilities will successfully detect and mitigate the Siloscape malware.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119168\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 10. Choosing action for unexpected processes on Prisma Cloud.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nPrisma Cloud\u2019s Runtime Protection feature learns the machine\u2019s behavior and creates a set of rules for processes. Once the learning is complete, the user can choose the action for new, unexpected processes attempting to execute. The user can choose to alert, prevent or completely block the execution.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_119170\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 11. Siloscape blocked by Prisma Cloud[\/caption]\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDescription\r\nSHA256\r\n\r\n\r\nOur Siloscape variant\r\n5B7A23676EE1953247A0364AC431B193E32C952CF17B205D36F800C270753FCB\r\n\r\n\r\nunzip.exe, the unzip binary Siloscape writes to the disk\r\n81046F943D26501561612A629D8BE95AF254BC161011BA8A62D25C34C16D6D2A\r\n\r\n\r\ntor.zip, the tor archive Silsocape writes to the disk\r\n010859BA20684AEABA986928A28E1AF219BAEBBF51B273FF47CB382987373DB7\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\nUnit 42 Discovers First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers\r\n\r\nWebinar: Unit 42 researchers will cover the details of Siloscape live.","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/02_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Daniel Prizmant"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />
<style id='co-authors-plus-coauthors-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow [class*=wp-block-co-authors-plus]{display:inline}

</style>

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-image-style-inline-css'>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-119145 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>
      </div>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">
        <button class="btn__search" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#search" aria-label="search"><i class="ui ui-1"></i></button>
      </div>

      <div id="search" class="collapse d-sm-block col-sm-auto col-12 ml-auto order-3">

                      <input type="search" placeholder="Search Unit 42" id="innerSearch" class="header__search" value="" required aria-label="Inner Search">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

</ul>  </div>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/02_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" title="Cloud Cybersecurity Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:hero:breadcrumb:Cloud Cybersecurity Research">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</a></li> </ul>

              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:hero:Cloud Cybersecurity Research"><span class="ab-title__pre">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</span></a> 
              <h1>Siloscape: First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers to Compromise Cloud Environments</h1>
              <div class="ab__video">

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Siloscape:%20First%20Known%20Malware%20Targeting%20Windows%20Containers%20to%20Compromise%20Cloud%20Environments%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fsiloscape%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/siloscape/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-119145-_46h2p8tm41zb"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>In March 2021, I uncovered the first known malware targeting Windows containers, a development that is not surprising given the massive surge in cloud adoption over the past few years. I named the malware Siloscape (sounds like silo escape) because its primary goal is to <em>escape</em> the container, and in Windows this <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/what-i-learned-from-reverse-engineering-windows-containers/">is implemented mainly by a server silo</a>.</p>
<p>Siloscape is heavily obfuscated malware targeting Kubernetes clusters through Windows containers. Its main purpose is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers.</p>
<p>Compromising an entire cluster is much more severe than compromising an individual container, as a cluster could run multiple cloud applications whereas an individual container usually runs a single cloud application. For example, the attacker might be able to steal critical information such as usernames and passwords, an organization’s confidential and internal files or even entire databases hosted in the cluster. Such an attack could even be leveraged as a ransomware attack by taking the organization's files hostage. Even worse, with organizations moving to the cloud, many use Kubernetes clusters as their development and testing environments, and a breach of such an environment can lead to devastating software supply chain attacks.</p>
<p>Siloscape uses the Tor proxy and an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.onion</span> domain to anonymously connect to its command and control (C2) server. I managed to gain access to this server. We identified 23 active Siloscape victims and discovered that the server was being used to host 313 users in total, implying that Siloscape was a small part of a broader campaign. I also discovered that this campaign has been taking place for more than a year.</p>
<p>This report provides background on Windows container vulnerabilities, gives a technical overview of Siloscape and offers recommendations on best practices for securing Windows containers.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are protected from this threat with <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud.html">Prisma Cloud’s</a> Runtime Protection features.</p>
<h2><a id="post-119145-_tw961pwfxc30"></a>Windows Server Container Vulnerabilities Overview</h2>
<p>On July 15, 2020, I released an <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/windows-server-containers-vulnerabilities/">article about Windows container boundaries</a> and how to break them. In that article, I presented a technique for escaping from a container and discussed some potential applications that such an escape can have in the hands of an attacker. The most significant application, and the one I chose to focus on, was an escape from a Windows container node in Kubernetes in order to spread in the cluster.</p>
<p>Microsoft originally didn’t consider this issue a vulnerability, based on the reasoning that Windows Server containers are not a security boundary, and therefore each application that is being run inside a container should be treated as if it is executed directly on the host.</p>
<p>A few weeks after that discussion, I reported the issue to Google because Kubernetes is vulnerable to those issues. <a href="https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/04/who-contains-containers.html">Google contacted Microsoft</a>, and after some back and forth, it was determined by Microsoft that an escape from a Windows container to the host, when executed without administrator permissions inside the container, <a href="https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-24096">will in fact be considered a vulnerability</a>.</p>
<p>Following this, I discovered Siloscape, which is malware that actively attempts to exploit Windows Server containers in the wild. Siloscape is heavily obfuscated malware targeting Kubernetes through Windows containers (using Server Containers and not Hyper-V). Its main purpose is to open a backdoor into poorly configured Kubernetes clusters in order to run malicious containers such as, but not limited to, cryptojackers.</p>
<p>The malware is characterized by several behaviors and techniques:</p>
<ul>
<li>Targets common cloud applications such as web servers for initial access, using known vulnerabilities (“1-days”) – presumably those with a working exploit in the wild.</li>
<li>Uses Windows container escape techniques to escape the container and gain code execution on the underlying node.</li>
<li>Attempts to abuse the node's credentials to spread in the cluster.</li>
<li>Connects to its C2 server using the IRC protocol over the Tor network.</li>
<li>Waits for further commands.</li>
</ul>
<p>This malware can leverage the computing resources in a Kubernetes cluster for cryptojacking and potentially exfiltrate sensitive data from hundreds of applications running in the compromised clusters.</p>
<p>Investigating the C2 server showed that this malware is just a small part of a larger network and that this campaign has been taking place for over a year. Furthermore, I confirmed that this specific part of the campaign was online with active victims at the time of writing.</p>
<h2><a id="post-119145-_nubxqo15w0c4"></a>Technical Overview</h2>
<p>Before diving into the technical details of Siloscape, it is important to get a better understanding of its overall behavior and flow.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119150" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119150" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119150" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image.jpeg" alt="The diagram shows the overall execution flow of Siloscape, including its communications with its C2 server and its movement through a poorly configured Kubernetes cluster. " width="900" height="572" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119150" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Execution flow of Siloscape.</figcaption></figure>
<ol>
<li>The attacker achieves remote code execution (RCE) inside a Windows container using a known vulnerability or a vulnerable web page or database.</li>
<li>The attacker executes Siloscape (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CloudMalware.exe</span>) with the necessary C2 connection information provided as command line arguments (and not hardcoded inside the binary).</li>
<li>Siloscape impersonates <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CExecSvc.exe</span> to obtain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SeTcbPrivilege</span> privileges (this technique is described in detail in my <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/windows-server-containers-vulnerabilities/">previous article</a>).</li>
<li>Siloscape creates a global symbolic link to the host, practically linking its containerized X drive to the host’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C</span> drive.</li>
<li>Siloscape searches for the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kubectl.exe</span> binary by name and the Kubernetes config file by regular expression on the host, using the global link.</li>
<li>Siloscape checks if the compromised node has enough privilege to create new Kubernetes deployments.</li>
<li>Siloscape extracts the Tor client to the disk from an archived file using an unzip binary. Both files are packed into the main Siloscape binary.</li>
<li>Siloscape connects to the Tor network.</li>
<li>Using the provided command line argument, Siloscape decrypts the C2 server’s password.</li>
<li>Siloscape connects to the C2 server using an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">.onion</span> domain (a domain accessible through the Tor network) provided as a command line argument.</li>
<li>Siloscape waits for commands from the C2 and executes them.</li>
</ol>
<p>Unlike other malware targeting containers, which are mostly cryptojacking-focused, Siloscape doesn’t actually do anything that will harm the cluster on its own. Instead, it focuses on being undetected and untraceable and opens a backdoor to the cluster.</p>
<h4><a id="post-119145-_blgbgt71xoo6"></a>Defense Evasion and Obfuscation</h4>
<p>Siloscape is heavily obfuscated. There are almost no readable strings in the entire binary. While the obfuscation logic itself isn’t complicated, it made reversing this binary frustrating.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119152" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119152" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119152" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-11.png" alt="A view of how strings from Siloscape appear in Interactive Dissembler shows how heavily obfuscated the malware is. " width="900" height="424" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119152" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Strings obfuscation as it looks in Interactive Disassembler (IDA).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Even simple API calls were obfuscated, and instead of just calling the functions, Siloscape made the effort to use the Native API (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NTAPI</span>) version of the same function.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119154" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119154" style="width: 734px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119154" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-12.png" alt="Dynamic search of functions in ntdll.dll" width="734" height="1072" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119154" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Dynamic search of functions in ntdll.dll.</figcaption></figure>
<p>For example, instead of calling <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CreateFile</span>, Siloscape calls <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtCreateFile</span>. Instead of calling <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtCreateFile</span> directly, Siloscape calls it dynamically, meaning it searches for the function name in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ntdll.dll</span> at runtime and jumps to its address. Not only that, but it also obfuscates the function and module names and deobfuscates them only at runtime. The end result is malware that is very difficult to detect with static analysis tools and frustrating to reverse engineer.</p>
<p>Siloscape uses a pair of keys to decrypt the C2 server’s password. One of the most important features of its obfuscation is that one key is hardcoded into the binary, while the other is supplied as a command line argument. I searched for its hash in multiple engines, such as <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/autofocus">AutoFocus</a> and VirusTotal, and couldn’t find any results. This led me to believe that Siloscape is being compiled uniquely for each new attack, using a unique pair of keys. The hardcoded key makes each binary a little bit different than the rest, which explains why I couldn’t find its hash anywhere. It also makes it impossible to detect Siloscape by hash alone.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119156" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119156" style="width: 783px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119156" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-13.png" alt="Siloscape uses Visual Studio Resource Manager to write the Tor archive to the disk" width="783" height="700" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119156" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Siloscape using Visual Studio Resource Manager.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Another interesting technique this malware uses is Visual Studio’s Resource Manager. This is a feature built into Visual Studio that allows one to attach basically any file to the original binary and get a pointer to its data with a few simple API calls. Siloscape uses this method to write the Tor archive to the disk, as well as the unzip binary used to open the archive. It also uses Tor to securely connect to its C2.</p>
<h4><a id="post-119145-_7syonfjyxwql"></a>The Container Escape</h4>
<p>One of the more interesting things about Siloscape is the way it escapes the container. To execute the system call <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtSetInformationSymbolicLink</span> that enables the escape, one must gain <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SeTcbPrivilege</span> first. There are a few ways to do this. For example, in my tests, I injected a DLL into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CExecSvc.exe</span>, which has the relevant privileges, and executed NtSetInformationSymbolicLink from the CExecSvc.exe context. Siloscape, however, uses a technique called Thread Impersonation. This method has little documentation online and even fewer working examples. The most critical function for this technique is the <strong>undocumented</strong> system call NtImpersonateThread.</p>
<p>Siloscape mimics <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CExecSvc.exe</span> privileges by impersonating its main thread and then calls <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NtSetInformationSymbolicLink</span> on a newly created symbolic link to break out of the container. More specifically, it links its local containerized <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">X</span> drive to the host’s C drive.</p>
<h4><a id="post-119145-_uz4rwhg5bsye"></a>Choosing the Cluster</h4>
<p>After Siloscape creates a link to the host, it will search for two specific files: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kubectl.exe</span> and the Kubernetes config file, which normally exists on Kubernetes nodes.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119158" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119158" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119158" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-14.png" alt="Siloscape searches for the kubectl.exe binary." width="900" height="130" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119158" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Siloscape searches for the kubectl.exe binary.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Siloscape searches for <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kubectl.exe</span> by name and the config file using a regular expression. The search function takes an extra argument: a pointer to a vector that holds folder names to exclude from the search.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119160" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119160" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119160" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-15.png" alt="Siloscape searches for the config file by regular expression." width="900" height="91" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119160" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Siloscape searches for the config file by regular expression.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When it calls <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">FindFile</span> to search for the above files, it excludes the folders Program Files, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Program Files (x86)</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Windows</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Users</span>. It does this to make the search faster and because it is unlikely the previously mentioned files are in those folders. If both files are found, their paths are saved to a global variable. If the files are not located, Siloscape exits, abandoning the attack.</p>
<p>After Siloscape finds everything it needs to execute kubectl commands, it continues to check if the compromised node actually has enough permissions to use for the attacker’s malicious activities. It does this by executing the kubectl command <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%ls auth can-i create deployments --kubeconfig=%ls</span> where the strings in the format are replaced by the paths it saved earlier as global variables.</p>
<h4><a id="post-119145-_u5v6bzbzdta"></a>Connecting to the C2 and Supported Commands</h4>
<p>After getting everything it needs and checking that the compromised node is indeed capable of creating new deployments, Siloscape writes the Tor archive (ZIP) and an unzip binary to the host’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C</span> drive. After extracting Tor, it launches <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tor.exe</span> to a new thread and waits for it to finish by checking the Tor thread output.</p>
<p>After Tor is up and running, Siloscape uses it to connect to its C2 – an IRC server, using an <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">onion</span> address that was provided as a command line argument.</p>
<p>The server is password-protected. Siloscape uses its first command line argument to decrypt the password by a simple byte by byte XOR. The following is a simplified version of the C2 server’s password decryption:</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">char hardCodedXor[32] = "HARD_CODED_32_LONG_STRING"; </span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">char ircPass[32] = { 0 }; </span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">for (int i = 0; i &lt; 32; i++) </span><br />
<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">     ircPass[i] = hardCodedXor[i] ^ argv[1][i];</span></p>
<p>Once successfully connected to the IRC server, it issues a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">JOIN</span> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">#WindowsKubernetes</span> command to join the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WindowsKubernetes</span> IRC channel and then idles there.</p>
<p>Siloscape allows two types of instructions, one for kubectl supported commands and one for regular Windows <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd</span> commands.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119162" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119162" style="width: 523px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119162" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-16.png" alt="Siloscape comparing the sender’s username to admin." width="523" height="369" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119162" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Siloscape comparing the sender’s username to admin.</figcaption></figure>
<p>It waits for a private message. If one from a user named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">admin</span> is received, Siloscape follows the following logic:</p>
<ul>
<li>If the message starts with a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">K</span>, it executes a kubectl command to the cluster using the paths it found earlier by running the command <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%ls %s --kubeconfig=%ls</span> where:
<ul>
<li>The first parameter is the global variable of the kubectl’s path.</li>
<li>The second parameter is the message from the admin minus the first character.</li>
<li>The third parameter is the global variable of the config’s path.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>If the message starts with a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C</span>, it simply runs the command minus the first character as a regular Windows <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cmd</span> command.</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-119145-_pl3p0kmjfjy8"></a>Command and Control</h2>
<p>After I reversed the malware, especially the part that handles the C2, I wanted to discover whether this campaign was still up and running.</p>
<p>I set up a brand new virtual machine, downloaded Tor and started looking for an IRC client that supports <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SOCKS5</span>, the proxy protocol that is needed in order to connect through Tor. IRC is a very old protocol and is less popular today than it was 20 years ago. Furthermore, IRC came out almost a decade before <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SOCKS5</span>. I found HexChat, a simple, lightweight IRC client that supports both <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">SOCKS5</span> and connecting to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">onion</span> domains.</p>
<p>When our Silospace sample was originally executed, its command line argument for the IRC username was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">php_35</span>, so I decided to use this username when connecting to the C2 server from HexChat, thinking it would appear legitimate to the attacker.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119164" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119164" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119164" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-17.png" alt="After connecting to the C2 server from HexChat, we observed the screen shown here, which lists active victims of the malware. " width="900" height="476" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119164" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. #WindowsKubernetes channel active victims.</figcaption></figure>
<p>I connected to the server and discovered it was still working. I joined <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">#WindowsKubernetes</span> just like Siloscape does. There were 23 active victims there and a channel operator named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">admin</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119166" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119166" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119166" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-18.png" alt="The screen shown here is what we observed after being noticed in the C2 server and kicked out. " width="900" height="474" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119166" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. C2 server shutting down.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Unfortunately, after about two minutes, I was noticed and kicked out of the server. Two minutes after that, the server was no longer active – at least not at the original <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">onion</span> domain I used.</p>
<h3><a id="post-119145-_34vzolo3eddd"></a>What Can We Learn?</h3>
<p>When I went over my findings, the first thing that came to mind is that there were many more active users on the C2 server than I actually saw in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">#WindowsKubernetes</span> channel – 313 users in total, to be exact. This implies that the Siloscape malware was just a small part of a bigger campaign.</p>
<p>Sadly, when I connected to the server, the channels list was empty, indicating that the server was configured to not reveal its channels. Therefore, I couldn’t get more information from the channel names.</p>
<p>The second and more important detail that stood out was the convention used for the victims’ names. Our name was <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">php_35</span>, and when our sample of Siloscape first executed, it indeed was executed through a vulnerable php instance. The other names clearly suggest the way the attacker managed to achieve code execution (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sqlinj</span> probably means SQL injection):</p>
<p><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">@admin sqlinj_64 sqlinj_51 php_34 weblogic_12 sqlinj_138 weblogic_19 php_66 sqlinj_87 sqlinj_8 sqlinj_33 sqlinj_114 activemq_5 sqlinj_44 tomcat_9 sqlinj_52 sqlinj_107 redis_10 php_76 sqlinj_28 activemq_25 sqlinj_35 php_8 weblogic_31 php_35</span></p>
<p>The last piece of information I was able to obtain from the C2 is the creation date of the server: Jan. 12, 2020. Note that this doesn’t necessarily mean that Siloscape was created on that date. Instead, it’s likely the campaign started at that time.</p>
<h2><a id="post-119145-_b3kkzmgjsh5w"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Unlike most cloud malware, which mostly focuses on resource hijacking and denial of service (DoS), Siloscape doesn’t limit itself to any specific goal. Instead, it opens a backdoor to all kinds of malicious activities.</p>
<p>As discussed in my <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/windows-server-containers-vulnerabilities/">last article</a>, users should follow Microsoft’s guidance recommending not to use Windows containers as a security feature. Microsoft recommends using strictly Hyper-V containers for anything that relies on containerization as a security boundary. Any process running in Windows Server containers should be assumed to have the same privileges as admin on the host, which in this case is the Kubernetes node. If you are running applications in Windows Server containers that need to be secured, we recommend moving these applications to Hyper-V containers.</p>
<p>Furthermore, administrators should make sure their Kubernetes cluster is securely configured. In particular, a secured Kubernetes cluster won’t be as vulnerable to this specific malware as the nodes’ privileges won’t suffice to create new deployments. In this case, Siloscape will exit.</p>
<p>Siloscape shows us the importance of container security, as the malware wouldn’t be able to cause any significant damage if not for the container escape. It is critical that organizations keep a well-configured and secured cloud environment to protect against such threats.</p>
<p>Existing <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/prisma/prisma-cloud.html">Prisma Cloud</a> capabilities will successfully detect and mitigate the Siloscape malware.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119168" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119168" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119168" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-19.png" alt="This shows how Prisma Cloud allows a user to choose what action to take in response to unexpected processes beginning to run on an environment. This is part of the Anti-malware and exploit prevention feature. " width="900" height="751" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119168" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Choosing action for unexpected processes on Prisma Cloud.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Prisma Cloud’s Runtime Protection feature learns the machine’s behavior and creates a set of rules for processes. Once the learning is complete, the user can choose the action for new, unexpected processes attempting to execute. The user can choose to alert, prevent or completely block the execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_119170" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-119170" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-119170" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/word-image-20.png" alt="The screenshot shows what Prisma Cloud displays when blocking Siloscape as an unexpected process. " width="900" height="532" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-119170" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Siloscape blocked by Prisma Cloud</figcaption></figure>
<h4><a id="post-119145-_v5y1qnn7ah5b"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h4>
<table style="width: 100.943%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 38.806%;"><strong>Description</strong></td>
<td style="width: 100.398%;"><strong>SHA256</strong></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 38.806%;">Our Siloscape variant</td>
<td style="width: 100.398%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5B7A23676EE1953247A0364AC431B193E32C952CF17B205D36F800C270753FCB</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 38.806%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">unzip.exe</span>, the unzip binary Siloscape writes to the disk</td>
<td style="width: 100.398%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">81046F943D26501561612A629D8BE95AF254BC161011BA8A62D25C34C16D6D2A</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 38.806%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tor.zip</span>, the tor archive Silsocape writes to the disk</td>
<td style="width: 100.398%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">010859BA20684AEABA986928A28E1AF219BAEBBF51B273FF47CB382987373DB7</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-119145-_b3kkzmgjsh5w"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/blog/2021/06/siloscape-malware-windows-containers">Unit 42 Discovers First Known Malware Targeting Windows Containers</a></p>
<p><a href="https://register.paloaltonetworks.com/newtargetedattack">Webinar:</a> Unit 42 researchers will cover the details of Siloscape live.</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 6 June, 2024 at 5:35 AM PDT</span>-->
              <button class="l-btn back-to-top" id="backToTop" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:back to top">Back to top</button>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/08_Security-Technology_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="A pictorial representation of a red team tool like Splinter.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-pentest-tool-splinter/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/red-teaming-tool/" title="red teaming tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:red teaming tool">Red teaming tool</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/pentest-tool/" title="pentest tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:pentest tool">Pentest tool</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/analysis-pentest-tool-splinter/" title="Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Discovering Splinter: A First Look at a New Post-Exploitation Red Team Tool:read now">
                    Read now                    <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-right-arrow-withtail.svg" alt="Right arrow">
                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/word-image-449925-135181-16-786x368.png" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Pictorial representation of APT groups from North Korea.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/gleaming-pisces-applejeus-poolrat-and-pondrat/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="siloscape:related-resources:Gleaming Pisces Poisoned Python Packages Campaign Delivers PondRAT Linux and MacOS Backdoors">

                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
